docs.lead_paragraph: It may be remembered as President Clinton's first post-election flip-flop, but he was right to let Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin correct his tactical error on the balanced-budget amendment. It was probably just a hangover from triangulation that caused Mr. Clinton to say Tuesday that he could live with the balanced-budget amendment if the Republicans in Congress pushed it through. The Wednesday morning headlines about Mr. Clinton's rush to surrender cleared everyone's thinking, and with White House blessings, Mr. Rubin said yesterday that the Administration will fight the Republicans' foolish passion for this paralyzing amendment. It is a fight worth making, because common sense has a chance to prevail. Mr. Clinton's basic instincts are correct. He told reporters on Tuesday that the amendment is unnecessary. But in an excess of his habitual pliability, he added that the amendment could be acceptable if it included an ''escape hatch'' during recessions. The problem with this formulation was that it ripped the political cover that a President fresh from an electoral landslide can offer to Democrats and renegade Republicans brave enough to vote no on this popular yet harmful proposal. Mr. Clinton helped defeat it last year, and now that Mr. Rubin has stiffened his spine, he could win again this year despite the Republican control on Capitol Hill.
docs.abstract: Editorial says Pres Clinton was correct in retreating from earlier suggestion that he could live with balanced-budget amendment if Republicans succeed in passing it; urges Administration to fight Republicans' foolish passion to pass paralyzing amendment (M)
docs.snippet: It may be remembered as President Clinton's first post-election flip-flop, but he was right to let Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin correct his tactical error on the balanced-budget amendment. It was probably just a hangover from triangulation that...

docs.lead_paragraph: ASHER JASON had a stack of medical documents to prove that his hospital had overcharged him. His health plan and the hospital had agreed that his colonoscopy 18 months ago should have cost $339. So he wondered why he kept receiving a bill for $1,476. For almost a year, Mr. Jason, a New York literary agent, tried to correct the overcharge. But he said he got only recorded messages when he tried calling the billing department. His letters, he added, were similarly ignored. ''They were about to wreck my credit,'' he recalled.

headline.main: Hiring a Consultant to Do Battle When a Medical Bill Seems Unfair

docs.abstract: Patients contesting large hospital bills are increasingly turning to independent medical claims adjusters for help; these consultants are also available to help employees choose among competing health plans, review existing policies, and process routine claims for those overwhelmed by medical paperwork; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: States are in robust financial condition as they prepare to take greater responsibility for welfare and other domestic programs, the National Governors' Association reported today. Raymond C. Scheppach, executive director of the association, said: ''The fiscal condition of states is good. Surpluses are up. For the third consecutive year, states are generally reducing taxes and fees.''

headline.main: Governors' Group Says States Are in Good Fiscal Condition

docs.abstract: Biannual fiscal report isued by National Governors' Association finds states are in robust financial condition; says favorable outlook reflects strength of national economy and several other factors (M)
docs.snippet: States are in robust financial condition as they prepare to take greater responsibility for welfare and other domestic programs, the National Governors' Association reported today.    Raymond C. Scheppach, executive director of the association, said:...

docs.lead_paragraph: Bowing to political reality, President Clinton today softened his opposition to a constitutional amendment to balance the Federal budget, even as he received a polite but noncommittal response from Congressional Republicans to a range of issues on his agenda for the coming year. ''I don't believe that we need it, but if we have it, it ought to be able to be implemented in a way that actually works and gives the country what it needs to manage a recession,'' Mr. Clinton said of the budget amendment, which seems likely to pass Congress.

headline.main: CLINTON SUGGESTS HE MAY NOT RESIST FISCAL AMENDMENT

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton bows to political reality by softening opposition to Constitutional amendment to balance Federal budget; says he does not believe amendment is necessary but that, if enacted, should be implemented in way that actually works and gives country what it needs to handle recession; defeat of balanced-budget measure by one vote in Senate in '95 after Clinton lobbied against it noted; recent gain of two Senate seats by Republicans has made passage more likely in 105th Congress; Senate majority leader Trent Lott and House Speaker Newt Gingrich say they are in no hurry to act on Clinton's pending proposals to balance budget, overhaul campaign finance laws and to establish commission to address long-term solvency of Medicare (M)
docs.snippet: Bowing to political reality, President Clinton today softened his opposition to a constitutional amendment to balance the Federal budget, even as he received a polite but noncommittal response from Congressional Republicans to a range of issues on...

docs.lead_paragraph: And now for Round 2 of the Battle of the New York Coliseum. City and state officials must settle two questions. The first is old and nettlesome: What should a new building in one of the city's most famed public spaces look like? The second may be more of a surprise: What's an appropriate use?

headline.main: Coliseum Proposals Attempt To Reflect City's Direction
headline.kicker: Trying to Construct A Mirror of Manhattan

docs.abstract: City and state officials are considering nine development proposals for New York Coliseum site; proposals, coming from some of nation's largest real estate companies, have radically changed nature of New York City's most contentious development debate; during 1980's, when current push for new development began, it seemed all but assured that any new structure on Coliseum site would be for corporate offices or high-priced apartments; now, possibilities for unused exhibition space erected in 1956 seem endless; development proposals summarized; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Nearly 100 million Americans have chronic diseases or disabilities, and caring for them accounts for three-fourths of the nation's health spending, researchers reported today. Most people with chronic conditions live normal lives, but they have higher health costs than other people, and they are more likely to be absent from work, the researchers said in a study in the Journal of the American Medical Association.

headline.main: Chronic Illness Has Vast Cost, A Study Finds

docs.abstract: University of California researchers report nearly 100 million Americans have chronic diseases or disabilities, and that caring for them accounts for three-fourths of nation's health spending (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Contrary to Peter Passell's Nov. 7 Economic Scene column, Oregonians did not reject a business outlook when they approved a ballot measure increasing the tobacco tax to finance Oregon's health plan.

headline.main: Oregon's Health Plan Means Good Business

docs.abstract: Theodore C Falk letter disputes Peter Passell's November 7 Economic Scene column on Oregon's health care system (M)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Contrary to Peter Passell's Nov. 7 Economic Scene column, Oregonians did not reject a business outlook when they approved a ballot measure increasing the tobacco tax to finance Oregon's health plan.

docs.lead_paragraph: Harold M. Ickes, a deputy White House chief of staff, 25-year friend of President Clinton and one of the architects of the President's re-election, will leave his job after being passed over for chief of staff, but may seek a post elsewhere in the Administration. Mr. Ickes, a liberal New York labor lawyer, declined to discuss the circumstances of his resignation, but friends said he was hurt that Mr. Clinton had not informed him of his decision to hire Erskine B. Bowles as White House chief of staff before it was announced on Friday. Mr. Ickes had aspired to the top job, though friends say he knew he was a long shot, given the President's stated determination to form a moderate, bipartisan team for his second term.

headline.main: Ickes, Longtime Clinton Ally, to Quit as No. 2 Chief of Staff

docs.abstract: Harold M Ickes, deputy White House chief of staff, 25-year friend of Pres Clinton and one of architects of his re-election campaign, will leave job after being passed over for chief of staff, but may seek post elsewhere in Administration; is reportedly upset that Clinton failed to inform him of decision to hire Erskine B Bowles for position; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Harold M. Ickes, a deputy White House chief of staff, 25-year friend of President Clinton and one of the architects of the President's re-election, will leave his job after being passed over for chief of staff, but may seek a post elsewhere in the...

docs.lead_paragraph: Proposing the biggest changes in the 60-year history of the state's welfare system, Gov. George E. Pataki will offer legislation this week to cut the monthly grants of hundreds of thousands of poor families and end cash benefits for many immigrants and able-bodied childless adults, his aides said today. The plan, which Mr. Pataki is expected to announce on Wednesday, is intended to bring New York State into compliance with the broad rules laid down in the new Federal welfare law, and represents his opening bid in negotiations with the Legislature. Those talks, which will begin in earnest when Mr. Pataki presents his 1998 budget in January, are likely to be drawn out and bitter, if past years are any guide.

headline.main: Pataki Welfare Plan Would Cut Payments to Families Over Time

docs.abstract: Gov George E Pataki, proposing biggest changes in 60-year history of New York State's welfare system, reportedly will offer legislation to cut monthly grants of hundreds of thousands of poor families and end cash benefits for many immigrants and able-bodied childless adults; plan is aimed at bringing state into compliance with new Federal welfare rules, and represents Pataki's opening bid in negotiations with Legislature; calls for reduction of monthly benefits by 10 percent after family has been on welfare for 18 months, after which benefits will be cut in stages during next three years for total reduction of 45 percent; after five years, families will be dropped from rolls entirely as mandated by Federal law; charts (M)
docs.snippet: Proposing the biggest changes in the 60-year history of the state's welfare system, Gov. George E. Pataki will offer legislation this week to cut the monthly grants of hundreds of thousands of poor families and end cash benefits for many immigrants...
docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: International A3-9 13 KILLED IN ATTACK IN MOSCOW In a grisly show of the growing audacity of Russia's criminal gangs, at least 13 people were killed and dozens wounded when a remote-controlled bomb ripped through a crowd of mourners at a cemetery in Moscow. A1 SPAIN'S WAR VETERANS SALUTED Veterans of the International Brigades, who gathered 60 years ago from Europe and North America to fight fascism in the Spanish Civil War, returned for what may be their last big reunion. A1 CASTRO UNSETTLES LATIN LEADERS As Latin American leaders gathered in Chile for an annual summit conference, a bitter debate erupted over Fidel Castro's presence at the meeting, which is focusing on the expansion of democracy. A3 BOSNIAN SERB GENERAL REPLACED Bosnian Serb political leaders, trying to assert control over their army, swore in new military commanders after the dismissal of Gen. Ratko Mladic, who has been indicted for war crimes. A3 AFRICA'S CRIPPLED GIANT Despite the small size of the rebel forces that have seized towns in eastern Zaire, few can see any way for Central Africa's crippled giant to regain the land by force. A6 PALESTINIAN KILLED IN PROTEST Israeli soldiers shot and killed a Palestinian and wounded 11 others when a protest against the expansion of a Jewish settlement turned into a violent clash. A7 EFFORT TO REVIVE ULSTER TALKS A mainstream Roman Catholic political leader said he had made new proposals to the British Government to revive the flagging peace effort in Northern Ireland. A8 TRADE SANCTION FROM CHINA China announced a ban on imports of selected goods from the United States, stepping up a trade dispute with the Clinton Administration and sending a blunt signal that it will not easily succumb to pressure. A9 National A10-13, B8 FIXING HEALTH CARE BIT BY BIT Rather than proposing a grand scheme to redesign the health care system, the Administration is concentrating on developing incremental proposals to fill gaps in health insurance coverage. A1 DIFFERENCES RESURFACE Since the election there has been much talk by both parties of bipartisan spirit, but in broadcast interviews over the weekend cracks in that unity began to appear. A1 NEW TEXACO TAPE ANALYSIS Outside investigators hired by Texaco have concluded from an analysis of a tape recording that a senior company executive did not use a highly charged racial epithet at a 1994 meeting. A1 WALL ST. IN CYBERSPACE The Internet is bringing profound changes to Wall Street that hold a lot of promise -- and a lot of peril -- for powerful securities firms. A1 WHEN THE COLD LEFT Scientists in Florida have found a 10,000-year-old site that they say sheds light on how the people North America adjusted at the end of the most recent Ice Age. A10 A RECURRING NIGHTMARE Petaluma, Calif., was still recovering from the just-concluded Polly Klaas murder case when word of another attack on a young girl shook the community. A10 LEAVING THE F.A.A. David R. Hinson, who has resigned as head of the Federal Aviation Administration, reflected on his tenure, a time during which the agency had to deal with several devastating plane crashes. A11 CAMPUS AND COMMUNITY College campuses were once viewed as melting pots where mingling in the student union was the defining activity, but today E-mail is creating an inward-looking atmosphere where life is lived in front of a computer. A12 Metro Report B1-7 LOOKING AHEAD IN ALBANY With the election over, the stage has been set in Albany for a 1997 legislative session every bit as confrontational and protracted as the 1996 version, which produced the latest state budget in the country's history, legislators say.
